author: Grimms
text: Hard by a great forest dwelt a poor wood-cutter with his wife and his two children.

author: Grimms
text: The boy was called Hansel and the girl Gretel.

author: Grimms
text: He had little to bite and to break, and once when great dearth fell on the land, he could no longer procure even daily bread.

author: Grimms
text: Now when he thought over this by night in his bed, and tossed about in his anxiety, he groaned and said to his wife: "What is to become of us?

author: Grimms
text: How are we to feed our poor children, when we no longer have anything even for ourselves?"

author: Grimms
text: "I"ll tell you what, husband," answered the woman, "early tomorrow morning we will take the children out into the forest to where it is the thickest; there we will light a fire for them, and give each of them one more piece of bread, and then we will go to our work and leave them alone.

author: Grimms
text: They will not find the way home again, and we shall be rid of them."

author: Grimms
text: "No, wife," said the man, "I will not do that; how can I bear to leave my children alone in the forest?--the wild animals would soon come and tear them to pieces."

author: Grimms
text: "O, you fool!" said she, "then we must all four die of hunger, you may as well plane the planks for our coffins," and she left him no peace until he consented.

author: Grimms
text: "But I feel very sorry for the poor children, all the same," said the man.

author: Grimms
text: The two children had also not been able to sleep for hunger, and had heard what their stepmother had said to their father.

author: Grimms
text: Gretel wept bitter tears, and said to Hansel: "Now all is over with us."

author: Grimms
text: "Be quiet, Gretel," said Hansel, "do not distress yourself, I will soon find a way to help us."

author: Grimms
text: And when the old folks had fallen asleep, he got up, put on his little coat, opened the door below, and crept outside.

author: Grimms
text: The moon shone brightly, and the white pebbles which lay in front of the house glittered like real silver pennies.

author: Grimms
text: Hansel stooped and stuffed the little pocket of his coat with as many as he could get in.

author: Grimms
text: Then he went back and said to Gretel: "Be comforted, dear little sister, and sleep in peace, God will not forsake us," and he lay down again in his bed.

author: Grimms
text: When day dawned, but before the sun had risen, the woman came and awoke the two children, saying: "Get up, you sluggards! we are going into the forest to fetch wood."

author: Grimms
text: She gave each a little piece of bread, and said: "There is something for your dinner, but do not eat it up before then, for you will get nothing else."

author: Grimms
text: Gretel took the bread under her apron, as Hansel had the pebbles in his pocket.

author: Grimms
text: Then they all set out together on the way to the forest.

author: Grimms
text: When they had walked a short time, Hansel stood still and peeped back at the house, and did so again and again.

author: Grimms
text: His father said: "Hansel, what are you looking at there and staying behind for?

author: Grimms
text: Pay attention, and do not forget how to use your legs."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah, father," said Hansel, "I am looking at my little white cat, which is sitting up on the roof, and wants to say goodbye to me."

author: Grimms
text: The wife said: "Fool, that is not your little cat, that is the morning sun which is shining on the chimneys."

author: Grimms
text: Hansel, however, had not been looking back at the cat, but had been constantly throwing one of the white pebble-stones out of his pocket on the road.

author: Grimms
text: When they had reached the middle of the forest, the father said: "Now, children, pile up some wood, and I will light a fire that you may not be cold."

author: Grimms
text: Hansel and Gretel gathered brushwood together, as high as a little hill.

author: Grimms
text: The brushwood was lighted, and when the flames were burning very high, the woman said: "Now, children, lay yourselves down by the fire and rest, we will go into the forest and cut some wood.

author: Grimms
text: When we have done, we will come back and fetch you away."

author: Grimms
text: Hansel and Gretel sat by the fire, and when noon came, each ate a little piece of bread, and as they heard the strokes of the wood-axe they believed that their father was near.

author: Grimms
text: It was not the axe, however, but a branch which he had fastened to a withered tree which the wind was blowing backwards and forwards.

author: Grimms
text: And as they had been sitting such a long time, their eyes closed with fatigue, and they fell fast asleep.

author: Grimms
text: When at last they awoke, it was already dark night.

author: Grimms
text: Gretel began to cry and said: "How are we to get out of the forest now?"

author: Grimms
text: But Hansel comforted her and said: "Just wait a little, until the moon has risen, and then we will soon find the way."

author: Grimms
text: And when the full moon had risen, Hansel took his little sister by the hand, and followed the pebbles which shone like newly-coined silver pieces, and showed them the way.

author: Grimms
text: They walked the whole night long, and by break of day came once more to their father"s house.

author: Grimms
text: They knocked at the door, and when the woman opened it and saw that it was Hansel and Gretel, she said: "You naughty children, why have you slept so long in the forest?--we thought you were never coming back at all!"

author: Grimms
text: The father, however, rejoiced, for it had cut him to the heart to leave them behind alone.

author: Grimms
text: Not long afterwards, there was once more great dearth throughout the land, and the children heard their mother saying at night to their father: "Everything is eaten again, we have one half loaf left, and that is the end.

author: Grimms
text: The children must go, we will take them farther into the wood, so that they will not find their way out again; there is no other means of saving ourselves!"

author: Grimms
text: The man"s heart was heavy, and he thought: "It would be better for you to share the last mouthful with your children."

author: Grimms
text: The woman, however, would listen to nothing that he had to say, but scolded and reproached him.

author: Grimms
text: He who says A must say B, likewise, and as he had yielded the first time, he had to do so a second time also.

author: Grimms
text: The children, however, were still awake and had heard the conversation.

author: Grimms
text: When the old folks were asleep, Hansel again got up, and wanted to go out and pick up pebbles as he had done before, but the woman had locked the door, and Hansel could not get out.

author: Grimms
text: Nevertheless he comforted his little sister, and said: "Do not cry, Gretel, go to sleep quietly, the good God will help us."

author: Grimms
text: Early in the morning came the woman, and took the children out of their beds.

author: Grimms
text: Their piece of bread was given to them, but it was still smaller than the time before.

author: Grimms
text: On the way into the forest Hansel crumbled his in his pocket, and often stood still and threw a morsel on the ground.

author: Grimms
text: "Hansel, why do you stop and look round?" said the father, "go on."

author: Grimms
text: "I am looking back at my little pigeon which is sitting on the roof, and wants to say goodbye to me," answered Hansel.

author: Grimms
text: "Fool!" said the woman, "that is not your little pigeon, that is the morning sun that is shining on the chimney."

author: Grimms
text: Hansel, however little by little, threw all the crumbs on the path.

author: Grimms
text: The woman led the children still deeper into the forest, where they had never in their lives been before.

author: Grimms
text: Then a great fire was again made, and the mother said: "Just sit there, you children, and when you are tired you may sleep a little; we are going into the forest to cut wood, and in the evening when we are done, we will come and fetch you away."

author: Grimms
text: When it was noon, Gretel shared her piece of bread with Hansel, who had scattered his by the way.

author: Grimms
text: Then they fell asleep and evening passed, but no one came to the poor children.

author: Grimms
text: They did not awake until it was dark night, and Hansel comforted his little sister and said: "Just wait, Gretel, until the moon rises, and then we shall see the crumbs of bread which I have strewn about, they will show us our way home again."

author: Grimms
text: When the moon came they set out, but they found no crumbs, for the many thousands of birds which fly about in the woods and fields had picked them all up.

author: Grimms
text: Hansel said to Gretel: "We shall soon find the way," but they did not find it.

author: Grimms
text: They walked the whole night and all the next day too from morning till evening, but they did not get out of the forest, and were very hungry, for they had nothing to eat but two or three berries, which grew on the ground.

author: Grimms
text: And as they were so weary that their legs would carry them no longer, they lay down beneath a tree and fell asleep.

author: Grimms
text: It was now three mornings since they had left their father"s house.

author: Grimms
text: They began to walk again, but they always came deeper into the forest, and if help did not come soon, they must die of hunger and weariness.

author: Grimms
text: When it was mid-day, they saw a beautiful snow-white bird sitting on a bough, which sang so delightfully that they stood still and listened to it.

author: Grimms
text: And when its song was over, it spread its wings and flew away before them, and they followed it until they reached a little house, on the roof of which it alighted; and when they approached the little house they saw that it was built of bread and covered with cakes, but that the windows were of clear sugar.

author: Grimms
text: "We will set to work on that," said Hansel, "and have a good meal.

author: Grimms
text: I will eat a bit of the roof, and you Gretel, can eat some of the window, it will taste sweet."

author: Grimms
text: Hansel reached up above, and broke off a little of the roof to try how it tasted, and Gretel leant against the window and nibbled at the panes.

author: Grimms
text: Then a soft voice cried from the parlour:

author: Grimms
text: "Nibble, nibble, gnaw, Who is nibbling at my little house?"

author: Grimms
text: The children answered:

author: Grimms
text: "The wind, the wind, The heaven-born wind,"

author: Grimms
text: and went on eating without disturbing themselves.

author: Grimms
text: Hansel, who liked the taste of the roof, tore down a great piece of it, and Gretel pushed out the whole of one round window-pane, sat down, and enjoyed herself with it.

author: Grimms
text: Suddenly the door opened, and a woman as old as the hills, who supported herself on crutches, came creeping out.

author: Grimms
text: Hansel and Gretel were so terribly frightened that they let fall what they had in their hands.

author: Grimms
text: The old woman, however, nodded her head, and said: "Oh, you dear children, who has brought you here? do come in, and stay with me.

author: Grimms
text: No harm shall happen to you."

author: Grimms
text: She took them both by the hand, and led them into her little house.

author: Grimms
text: Then good food was set before them, milk and pancakes, with sugar, apples, and nuts.

author: Grimms
text: Afterwards two pretty little beds were covered with clean white linen, and Hansel and Gretel lay down in them, and thought they were in heaven.

author: Grimms
text: The old woman had only pretended to be so kind; she was in reality a wicked witch, who lay in wait for children, and had only built the little house of bread in order to entice them there.

author: Grimms
text: When a child fell into her power, she killed it, cooked and ate it, and that was a feast day with her.

author: Grimms
text: Witches have red eyes, and cannot see far, but they have a keen scent like the beasts, and are aware when human beings draw near.

author: Grimms
text: When Hansel and Gretel came into her neighbourhood, she laughed with malice, and said mockingly: "I have them, they shall not escape me again!"

author: Grimms
text: Early in the morning before the children were awake, she was already up, and when she saw both of them sleeping and looking so pretty, with their plump and rosy cheeks she muttered to herself: "That will be a dainty mouthful!"

author: Grimms
text: Then she seized Hansel with her shrivelled hand, carried him into a little stable, and locked him in behind a grated door.

author: Grimms
text: Scream as he might, it would not help him.

author: Grimms
text: Then she went to Gretel, shook her till she awoke, and cried: "Get up, lazy thing, fetch some water, and cook something good for your brother, he is in the stable outside, and is to be made fat.

author: Grimms
text: When he is fat, I will eat him."

author: Grimms
text: Gretel began to weep bitterly, but it was all in vain, for she was forced to do what the wicked witch commanded.

author: Grimms
text: And now the best food was cooked for poor Hansel, but Gretel got nothing but crab-shells.

author: Grimms
text: Every morning the woman crept to the little stable, and cried: "Hansel, stretch out your finger that I may feel if you will soon be fat."

author: Grimms
text: Hansel, however, stretched out a little bone to her, and the old woman, who had dim eyes, could not see it, and thought it was Hansel"s finger, and was astonished that there was no way of fattening him.

author: Grimms
text: When four weeks had gone by, and Hansel still remained thin, she was seized with impatience and would not wait any longer.

author: Grimms
text: "Now, then, Gretel," she cried to the girl, "stir yourself, and bring some water.

author: Grimms
text: Let Hansel be fat or lean, tomorrow I will kill him, and cook him."

author: Grimms
text: Ah, how the poor little sister did lament when she had to fetch the water, and how her tears did flow down her cheeks!

author: Grimms
text: "Dear God, do help us," she cried.

author: Grimms
text: "If the wild beasts in the forest had but devoured us, we should at any rate have died together."

author: Grimms
text: "Just keep your noise to yourself," said the old woman, "it won"t help you at all."

author: Grimms
text: Early in the morning, Gretel had to go out and hang up the cauldron with the water, and light the fire.

author: Grimms
text: "We will bake first," said the old woman, "I have already heated the oven, and kneaded the dough."

author: Grimms
text: She pushed poor Gretel out to the oven, from which flames of fire were already darting.

author: Grimms
text: "Creep in," said the witch, "and see if it is properly heated, so that we can put the bread in."

author: Grimms
text: And once Gretel was inside, she intended to shut the oven and let her bake in it, and then she would eat her, too.

author: Grimms
text: But Gretel saw what she had in mind, and said: "I do not know how I am to do it; how do I get in?"

author: Grimms
text: "Silly goose," said the old woman.

author: Grimms
text: "The door is big enough; just look, I can get in myself!" and she crept up and thrust her head into the oven.

author: Grimms
text: Then Gretel gave her a push that drove her far into it, and shut the iron door, and fastened the bolt.

author: Grimms
text: Oh! then she began to howl quite horribly, but Gretel ran away and the godless witch was miserably burnt to death.

author: Grimms
text: Gretel, however, ran like lightning to Hansel, opened his little stable, and cried: "Hansel, we are saved!

author: Grimms
text: The old witch is dead!"

author: Grimms
text: Then Hansel sprang like a bird from its cage when the door is opened.

author: Grimms
text: How they did rejoice and embrace each other, and dance about and kiss each other!

author: Grimms
text: And as they had no longer any need to fear her, they went into the witch"s house, and in every corner there stood chests full of pearls and jewels.

author: Grimms
text: "These are far better than pebbles!" said Hansel, and thrust into his pockets whatever could be got in, and Gretel said: "I, too, will take something home with me," and filled her pinafore full.

author: Grimms
text: "But now we must be off," said Hansel, "that we may get out of the witch"s forest."

author: Grimms
text: When they had walked for two hours, they came to a great stretch of water.

author: Grimms
text: "We cannot cross," said Hansel, "I see no foot-plank, and no bridge."

author: Grimms
text: "And there is also no ferry," answered Gretel, "but a white duck is swimming there: if I ask her, she will help us over."

author: Grimms
text: Then she cried:

author: Grimms
text: "Little duck, little duck, dost thou see, Hansel and Gretel are waiting for thee?

author: Grimms
text: There"s never a plank, or bridge in sight, Take us across on thy back so white."

author: Grimms
text: The duck came to them, and Hansel seated himself on its back, and told his sister to sit by him.

author: Grimms
text: "No," replied Gretel, "that will be too heavy for the little duck; she shall take us across, one after the other."

author: Grimms
text: The good little duck did so, and when they were once safely across and had walked for a short time, the forest seemed to be more and more familiar to them, and at length they saw from afar their father"s house.

author: Grimms
text: Then they began to run, rushed into the parlour, and threw themselves round their father"s neck.

author: Grimms
text: The man had not known one happy hour since he had left the children in the forest; the woman, however, was dead.

author: Grimms
text: Gretel emptied her pinafore until pearls and precious stones ran about the room, and Hansel threw one handful after another out of his pocket to add to them.

author: Grimms
text: Then all anxiety was at an end, and they lived together in perfect happiness.

author: Grimms
text: My tale is done, there runs a mouse; whosoever catches it, may make himself a big fur cap out of it.
